> --- In samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com, "Steve Gill" <Steve@c...>
> wrote:
> > It does come up with a rather fancy message telling me that I
> >haven't reached the reserve yet and should try raising my maximum
> >bid - which has no effect whatsoever.
> >

> regardless of you current bid?

To be honest I can't be sure, I did try some ridiculously large maximum bids
on one of them though.

---
Steve Gill

Is this what it would do if your maximum bid was below the reserve,
regardless of you current bid?

messages.subject: Re: Books for sale on Ebay
messages.msgSnippet: I m pretty sure all you have to do is increase your bid until you get to the reserve price, until that time, it won t matter, but once you raise it up to the
messages.messageBody:
I'm pretty sure all you have to do is increase your bid until you get
to the reserve price, until that time, it won't matter, but once you
raise it up to the reserve price, you'll be the high bidder. At
least that is how I understand it. The EBAY FAQ should tell you
exactly how it works. I've never created a reserve auction, but I've
bid in them before.


--- In samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com, "Steve Gill" <Steve@c...>
wrote:
> Except the Ebay systems won't allow me to raise my own bid unless
there's a
> bid to go against, all I can raise is my maximum bid, not my
current bid. It
> does come up with a rather fancy message telling me that I haven't
reached
> the reserve yet and should try raising my maximum bid - which has
no effect
> whatsoever.
>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Kitsuno
> >
> > That's correct, that's how it works.
> >
> >
> > --- In samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com, "mackyukuk"
<mike.macky@b...>
> > wrote:
> > > Steve, I may be wrong but as I understand it, you don't need
> > anyone
> > > else to bid against - you increase your own bid until you reach
> > the
> > > reserve, or your own limit if that comes first.
> > > The reserve was set at the price below which I would not sell,
the
> > > starting price is just that, it's there to attract some bids -
set
> > it
> > > too high and you scare people off.
> > > I may try these books again on Ebay in a few weeks.
> > >
> > > Mike

messages.subject: RE: [samuraihistory] Re: Books for sale on Ebay
messages.msgSnippet: Except the Ebay systems won t allow me to raise my own bid unless there s a bid to go against, all I can raise is my maximum bid, not my current bid. It does
messages.messageBody:
Except the Ebay systems won't allow me to raise my own bid unless there's a
bid to go against, all I can raise is my maximum bid, not my current bid. It
does come up with a rather fancy message telling me that I haven't reached
the reserve yet and should try raising my maximum bid - which has no effect
whatsoever.


> -----Original Message-----
> From: Kitsuno
>
> That's correct, that's how it works.
>
>
> --- In samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com, "mackyukuk" <mike.macky@b...>
> wrote:
> > Steve, I may be wrong but as I understand it, you don't need
> anyone
> > else to bid against - you increase your own bid until you reach
> the
> > reserve, or your own limit if that comes first.
> > The reserve was set at the price below which I would not sell, the
> > starting price is just that, it's there to attract some bids - set
> it
> > too high and you scare people off.
> > I may try these books again on Ebay in a few weeks.
> >
> > Mike
>
>
>
> Samurai Archives: http://www.samurai-archives.com

messages.subject: Re: Books for sale on Ebay
messages.msgSnippet: That s correct, that s how it works. ... anyone ... the ... it
messages.messageBody:
That's correct, that's how it works.


--- In samuraihistory@yahoogroups.com, "mackyukuk" <mike.macky@b...>
wrote:
> Steve, I may be wrong but as I understand it, you don't need
anyone
> else to bid against - you increase your own bid until you reach
the
> reserve, or your own limit if that comes first.
> The reserve was set at the price below which I would not sell, the
> starting price is just that, it's there to attract some bids - set
it
> too high and you scare people off.
> I may try these books again on Ebay in a few weeks.
>
> Mike

messages.subject: Re: Books for sale on Ebay
messages.msgSnippet: Steve, I may be wrong but as I understand it, you don t need anyone else to bid against - you increase your own bid until you reach the reserve, or your own
messages.messageBody:
Steve, I may be wrong but as I understand it, you don't need anyone
else to bid against - you increase your own bid until you reach the
reserve, or your own limit if that comes first.
The reserve was set at the price below which I would not sell, the
starting price is just that, it's there to attract some bids - set it
too high and you scare people off.
I may try these books again on Ebay in a few weeks.

Mike

messages.subject: RE: [samuraihistory] Books for sale on Ebay
messages.messageBody:
> From: mackyukuk [mailto:mike.macky@...]
>
>
> Hi all, I'm having a loft clearout and am selling some books on Ebay.
> These are my collection of books on Japanese armour and weapons which
> I put together a couple of decades ago. Hopefully they are of
> interest. Here are the first four, I will probably put some more up
> in a few days:
>

http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&category=1127&item=3551642858

http://cgi.ebay.com/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&category=1127&item=3551656954
>

Hmmm, not easy to bid on these books - the reserves are far higher than the
starting bid price which means that unless there are two of you willing to
bid up to the reserve nobody gets them (as happened to me on two;-( ).


---
Steve Gill

messages.messageBody:
Hi all, I'm having a loft clearout and am selling some books on Ebay.
These are my collection of books on Japanese armour and weapons which
I put together a couple of decades ago. Hopefully they are of
interest. Here are the first four, I will probably put some more up
in a few days:
